results.title: A Night at the opera
results.creator_credit: Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer, Irving G. Thalberg and Sam Wood
results.brief_description: This original comedy with sparkling dialogue, delightful music and of course the Marx brothers, is one of the funniest to come from the MGM studio. The action romps along at madcap pace as Groucho, Chico and Harpo go into the grand opera business in Italy, dash across the Atlantic and stage an opera in New York, that has the city on its ear. It is an opera such as has never been seen before. Rated: G

results.title: A Matter of life and death
results.creator_credit: Archers Film Productions, Independent Producers, Michael Powell and Emeric Pressburger
results.brief_description: Squadron Leader Peter Carter (David Niven), is caught between two worlds, reality, and the other which exists in his imagination that has been contaminated by war. As his plane travels over the English Channel in a ball of fire, he prepares to jump without a parachute. In what he believes are his final moments he shares his feelings on love and poetry with an American WAC, Kim Hunter. After he lands ashore he meets the WAC and they fall in love. All seems well, but a case of concussion causes Carter to experience hallucinations in which he finds himself on trial within his imaginary world. This film also features Raymond Massey, Roger Livesey and Richard Attenbourough. Also known as “Stairway to heaven”. Earthbound sequences are filmed in technicolour and Heaven sequences in black and white.

results.title: A Man for all seasons
results.brief_description: Robert Bolt’s literate and penetrating treatment of the conflict waged between Sir Thomas More and King Henry VIII makes a smooth transition to the screen. Zinnemann has mounted a film with an eye for characterisation rather than spectacle and the result is a superior drama. Stars Paul Scofield, Robert Shaw, Wendy Hiller, Orson Welles, Susannah York and Vanessa Redgrave. Rated: G

results.title: A Man escaped = Un Condamne a mort e'est echappe = Le Vent souffle ou il vent
results.creator_credit: Gaumont-British Instructional, Alain Poire, Jean Thuillier and Robert Bresson
results.brief_description: Based on the true life account of Resistance fighter Andre Devigny, who was imprisoned and condemned to death by the Nazis, “A Man Escaped” is one of cinema’s truly poetic films, a study in both the psychology of imprisonment and loss of liberty, as well as a tense and involving study of how a man plotted his escape from one of the most heavily guarded prisons in World War II. As played by Francois Letterier, the condemned man’s initial fear and anger give way to a resolve and determination to defy his fascist captors. But, as his plans are disturbed on the eve of his execution, he achieves a transcendence by accepting the inevitability of fate, the need to trust another human being, and finally having the knowledge that by not surrendering his will - whatever the outcome of his escape - he has truly liberated himself from the enemy. Winner of the Best Director Award a Cannes in 1957, stunningly photographed by L. H. Burel, and featuring an evocative use of Mozart’s Mass in C Minor, this is universally acknowledged as one of Bresson’s supreme works. In French with English subtitles.

results.title: A Man called Sledge
results.creator_credit: De Laurentiis Entertainment Group, Dino De Laurentiis and Vic Morrow
results.brief_description: Outlaw Luther Sledge (James Garner) sets out with his bandit gang to steal a half million dollar consignment of gold bullion which is shipped each week through a small western town. His scheme involves stealing the gold from within a local prison where it is held overnight. This daring escapade leads to a sequence of betrayals and a violent trail of vengeance across the Mexican border. This is a dramatic and fast-moving western which casts James Garner in the unusual role of villain, the supporting cast includes Dennis Weaver, Claude Akins and John Marley.

results.title: A Life less ordinary
results.creator_credit: Figment Films, Andrew Macdonald and Danny Boyle
results.brief_description: Acclaimed “Trainspotting” trio (director Danny Boyle, producer Andrew Macdonald, and screenwriter John Hodge) re-unite for this wacky romantic comedy. Two angels, O’Reilly (Holly Hunter) and Jackson (Delroy Lindo) are assigned to make two people fall in love. If they fail the angels will be stuck on earth forever. The targets of this matchmaking mission are Celine (Cameron Diaz), a heartless, rich woman with a penchant for guns, and Robert (Ewan McGregor), an aspiring pulp novelist who works as a janitor in the corporation owned by Celine’s father (Ian Holm). When Robert is sacked and replaced by a robot a chain of events begins which brings the two together. Robert attempts to kidnap Celine and get his job back, and Celine attempts to make Robert extort money from her father. Meanwhile angels O’Reilly and Jackson are working overtime to get Robert and Celine to fall in love, which isn’t easy seeing as the two mismatched kidnappers create chaos wherever they go. A quirky adventure romance, “A Life less ordinary” races along with a great soundtrack and moments of pure madness and fantasy (look out for the song and dance routine between Ewan McGregor and Cameron Diaz).

results.title: A Heart in winter = Un Coeur en hiver
results.creator_credit: Film Par Film, Cinea, Orly Films, SEDIF, D.A. Films, Paravision International, FR3, Jean-Louis Livi, Philippe Carcassonne and Claude Sautet
results.brief_description: Daniel Auteil and Emmanuelle Beart (the leading actors from Manon Des Sources) star in this triangular love story which explores the darker recesses of the heart and soul; where emotion is repressed. Two longtime friends in the classical music world find their friendship is threatened when a beautiful woman enters their lives. Ravel’s music forms a striking background to the drama as one woman embarks on a journey of surrender to passion.

results.title: A Hard day's night
results.creator_credit: United Artists Corporation, Walter Shenson and Richard Lester
results.brief_description: Starring the Beatles, this comic fantasia with music uses a multitude of cinematic gags. An enormous commercial success, it led directly to all the kaleidescope swinging London spy thrillers and comedies of the late sixties. In this film the Beatles, harrased by their manager and Paul’s grandpa, embark from Liverpool by train for a London television show.

results.title: A Handful of dust
results.creator_credit: New Line Cinema, Stagescreen, Derek Granger and Charles Sturridge
results.brief_description: Tony and Brenda Last (James Wilby and Kristin Scott Thomas) appear to be the perfect married ccouple - with money, position, a great country house and an adored son, John Andrew. When Tony inadvertently invites John Beaver (Rupert Graves), an idle and penniless young socialite, to stay for the weekend, he sets in motion a series of events which drastically disrupts the course of all their lives. Brenda drifts into an affair with the worthless Mr. Beaver, with disastrous consequences, particularly for Tony, who remains unaware of Brenda’s betrayal until the tragic death of their young son. As Brenda leaves home to take up a precarious life with her lover in London. Tony sets sail with an eccentric explorer on an expedition to the South American rain forests. Lost in the jungle and stricken by fever, Tony is rescued from death by the eccentric half-caste Mr. Todd (Alec Guinness) with unexpected and sinister results.

results.title: A Fistful of dollars = Per un pugno di dollari [Widescreen] (S)
results.creator_credit: Jolly Film, Harry Colombo, George Papi and Sergio Leone
results.brief_description: Clint Eastwood plays a cynical gunfighter who comes to a small border town and offers his services to two rivalling gangs. Neither gang is aware of his double play, and each thinks it is using him, but the stranger will outwit them both. This picture was the first instalment in a cycle commonly known as the “Dollars” trilogy, with “For a Few Dollars More” and “The Good, the Bad, and the Ugly” as follow-ups. Although the plot was admittedly borrowed from Kurosawa’s “Yojimbo”, the film contains all of Leone’s trademarks; taciturn characters, precise framing, extreme close-ups, and the haunting music of Ennio Morricone. Cast includes Marianne Koch, John Wells, W. Lukschy and Josef Egger.
